content: jos tahdot niin pattern and photos tiina kuu tech editing helena kahan jos tahdot niin is a sock with a basic construction where beginning of the round is carefully placed within the stranded colourwork and a special technique is applied in the latvian braid to make the jog at the bor less obvious the name of the pattern refers to a song titled jos sä tahdot niin by the finnish artist hector yarn and yardage colour 1 c1 freija yarn merino sock 75% merino 25% nylon 425 m / 100 g 20-30 other supplies grams of pale brown swan song colourway 3 stitch markers colour 2 c2 satuko design merino sock yarn a tapestry needle 85% merino 15% nylon 400 m / 100 g 50- 70 grams of gingerbread brown sizes any other fingering weight yarns can be used there are instructions for sizes extra-small 60 sts small 64 sts medium 68 sts large 72 sts and extra-large 76 sts which are gauge referred to in the instructions as xs s m l 36 sts and 44 row in stockinette with smaller xl if only one stitch count is given it applies needles = 10 cm / 4 inches to all sizes sizes xs s m l xl fit foot circumference of approximately 18 19 20 36 sts and 38 row in stranded colourwork 21 5 22 5 cm / 7 7½ 8 8½ 9 inches with with bigger needles = 10 cm / 4 inches some negative ease needles before you start 2 0 mm / us0 and 2 5 mm / us1½ or suitable please read the instructions carefully note to obtain gauge needles of your choice that the bor is shifted a few times use stitch the instructions have been written so that the markers to keep track of both bor and the type of needles used is not specified sides of the foot please note that a special technique called a hiding stitch or hs is used to make bor jog less obvious both in the latvian braid and the colour change on the foot the technique is described in detail at the end of the instructions jos tahdot niin socks page 1/6 instructions cuff with c1 and smaller needles cast on 60 68 for the second sock work a left-leaning 68 76 76 sts distribute sts across needles as latvian braid as follows desired join to begin working in the round round 1 *k1 with c2 k1 with c1* repeat * - * being careful not to twist place a bor marker to the end of the round if desired round 2 work a knit hs with c2 pm bring and work k1tbl p1 ribbing for 12 12 14 14 16 keep both c1 and c2 to the front *pick up c1 rnds or to desired length over c2 and p1 with c1 pick up c2 over c1 and p1 with c2 * repeat * - * to marker rm c1 and c2 will overlap
